reviews.review_text: Great underappreciated RPG. Big world, multiple ways to approach most quests, tons and tons of content. My favourite thing about the game is that you can read people's minds for a fee, leading to all sorts of cool situations.  Very recommended, give it a try if you have the time.

One of the few RPG that features heavy air battle, and lets you walk in air battle maps; One of the few RPG where you can almost mind read everybody, with voiced results; One of the few RPG where you have access to both crafted and random generated gears; One of the few RPG whose script writers still practice the forsaken art of limmericking; One of the few RPG where dodging attacks is actually fun and jumping around is not only glitch free and liberating.. the list goes on. This game puts loads of 'open world' games to shame in terms of what you are allowed to do.

First off, let me start by saying; GET THIS GAME.   I'll explain, I've played many open world (and closed) RPG games, and I can honestly say this rank among the top 3 for me. I played this game ALL THE TIME on the Xbox 360, and I'm SO GLAD that PC had a version of it aswell.  This game, is a game you can VERY EASILY sink hundreds of thousands of hours into, and I honestly mean that.  I'll get to the pros and cons, but seriously, just buy this game. PROS: The dialogue is funny, crisp, and refreshing. There are SO MANY WAYS to approach any scenario in the game. A conversation which can end in bloodshed can just as well end in a new ally gained. VERY GOOD if you enjoyed some of the older Dragon Age games. The storyline is amazing and feels so intricately designed. The characters are unique and memorable and bound to earn your love. The gameplay is dynamic and well polished.  Combat is intense and you have a vast array of weapons and spells to tailor to your liking. There are SO MANY quests, and each and every one of them feel unique and crafted with love, not following standard RPG clone formula. The music, the environment, the creatures, all of which are aesthetically pleasing on a grand scale. Every location is beautiful and unique, and you actually feel immersed. The load times are very short, which is nice when you just want to get into the game and play.  CONS: While I cannot necessarily fault the game for this, I still must bring it up. The content was heavily reduced and many features and areas were cut for the sake of portability to consoles. No mod support. I feel like this is key for maximizing the life span of an RPG game (look at bethesda titles.) Combat, while I did praise it in the Pros sections, it can be a tad bit clunky at times.   That's it. I really can't think of anything else to write here.  If you're like me, and love beautifully crafted games...buy this game. If you're STILL hesitant, at least get it on a sale, they have them pretty frequently.
'Victory is mine,' my character declared as she slayed a rabbit for the first time.

This game does NOT hold your hand. I thought playing oblivion was enough, but it obviously wasn't. There isn't a convenient marker that shows you exactly where to go. You have to memorize the direction given from NPCs and actually use clues given throughout the game.  Although that makes it alot harder, it does well to add immersion. I'm liking it so far.  The only gripe I have is the combat. It's a bit clunky and dated, and it shows. But everything else makes up for it enough to earn a thumbs up.

Rating: 8.5/10 Very Good  ===  NOTE PLEASE READ  I have only < 1h of game time because, since i have Windows 10, i must run the game via an external .exe to make it compatible. Steam does not log played time with this different .exe  I have played 100+ hours and did all side-quests i found.  ===    Pros & Cons

This. Game, Man!  This is one of the most inspired games out there, it's more than clear that this world was developed with love and passion over the desire to make profit and sales. Gameplay is somewhat floaty and will require some getting used to but offers an amazing range of variety and clear and significan progress as you level up.  The story is nothing too shocking but a good one nonethless, I enjoyed it even though it was predictable and average, you might not be to impressed here.  The game's world and art style is what drew me in the most, it has amazing towns, very classical looking while offering new area that will later spawn nostalgia if you play long enough.  Humor, something not common in RPG's but this one does splendidly well, even though they try and present this serious and critical situation of dragons and demons, the character's dialogue can be hilariously cliche and the developers clearly spent time focusing on making this game what it really is, a game. Of course one can demand immersion from RPG titles but do not go into this looking for that. The dialogue is clearly written to lighten up the feel of the game and bring smiles without breaking your experience.   Voice acting is mediocre with no lazy work, all characters are voiced professionally and respectfully. Although the game promises an open world, the player will have to make some progress before in the story to reach the core of the game, having the dragon power, and even then the game continues to be a challenging one.  In the end this stands a solid RPG made by a very dedicated and passionate team, although by no means a triple A title, the game holds a firm standing in the RPG genre as a unique and creative title. Play.This.Game.

This is one of the most fun RPG's I have played in awhile. Deep Skill customization to make the character like you want him or her to be. Want to be a unarmed preist who can beat his enemies into a pulp with his fist and summon deadly monsters to aid him, no promblem. Want to be a powerful mage who can still use a giant hammer and still be effective with that hammer while burning your foes in fire, go for it. I wish more games were like this one and that the devs would make another one like this instead of Divinity original sin or Dragon commander(still great games but I want another rpg third person game like this one) I give it a 10/10   If you don't like to know about the story don't read on some people may consider it a spoiler     The game also has a pretty awesome vilian named Damian who wants to destroy mankind for killing his girlfriend, he is soulbound to her before she died so he became immortal (soul bound is when you use magic to bind your souls, if you die, they die or reversed, but it also works on the soon to die in a different way). The game starts out as you being a initiate to a elite force of dragon hunters called the Slayers. Your mission is to hunt down the last dragon knight and put him or her to death. (dragon knights are people who can turn into dragons) well this dragon knight screws you over by forcing her powers on you and ruins your life. I'll let you figure out the rest. I give it a clear 10/10 can play the same game hundreds of times but to be warned it is almost as hard as darksouls on normal, so do every side quest before even thinking on taking on the bossess.

Excellent game, really enjoying it. The voice acting and dialogue is just great, always refreshing. I normally skip the boring RPG storys and the droning dialogue of main/side npc's, but in this game I look for people to talk to just to listen to the random interesting and often helpful things they come up with.   The story is just great all around, and I have been actively having fun the entire time I have played (bar the beginning half-hour of same-ol same-ol introduction).  The side quests are refreshing, with often intriguing story's and interesting things to try to accomplish and puzzles to complete.   I am always surprised when I stumble across yet another random secret, the lengths Larian Studios went to come up with so many secrets that I am sure many people never even see.  I would rate this in the top 5 RPG's I have ever played.

This game isn't Skyrim but that doesn't mean its not any good. This game has been one of my favorite RPGs. One that I will go back to time and time again. It can be over the top, cartoonish, and childish at times but thats what gives Divinity 2 its charm. Days worth of content await and much more for the player who's willing to overlook its dated gameplay and graphics. Combat may not be as easy and the entire experience may vary per person. Dialogue can range from rich to shallow humor, but with the amount of easter eggs and homages, one can be sure that conversation can be quite a treat. The dragon form is one of the best aspects of the game as it is unique in itself. I found myself flying a good bit of my playthrough and just attacking fortresses in the areas presented. There are some glitches and bugs that can make it a chore to play at times but nonetheless it is a very good game that blends two distinct genres. My only regret is that Larian wasn't able to make this game the way it was supposed to be due to budget cuts. Its not Skyrim or Dragon Age but it is still quite a gem of a game and highly underrated, that is if you are willing to overlook its flaws. 8/10.

I have only ever played this and Original Sin but I still feel this is true. Whilst the main game runs for about 40 hrs and the expansion another 10-20, I feel like there should have been more areas to explore.  Overall: Great game, get it, especially on sale. My cons in this cause are simply things I wish they could have done more with, what did do was superb.

I like this game but the sky and lighting for me was overpowering, even after messing with settings. It could be just an AMD thing, who knows?   The good   Big and strange world to explore. I stress strange Lots of different ways to configure your character Bright and dazzling world (but see the bad too) Interesting in-game lore and history  Doesn't hold your hand in regards to quest progression, what to do etc. Some pretty funny in-jokes and pop-culture references Amusing dialogue and voice-over at times Excellent spell and combat effects Mindreading people adds a new dimension to gameplay Great armour and weapon modelling Challenging boss fights Flying and fighting as a dragon!   The bad   Game takes its time to get going. You're halfway through it by the time you get to be a dragon, own a tower etc It could well be my graphics card (390x) but the world is very shiny and bronze-y, Everything glistens and reflects. Makes many environments washed out Occasionally weird and strange music that's off-putting, and a touch inappropriate for a fantasy game IMHO Some generic step and fetch it quests Game is brutal, even in easy mode Some very generic dungeons The fact that it can be difficult to figure out what to do next or where to go may throw off some players

If you like story-driven RPG games, I think you'll love Divinity 2. This game feels extremely deep and broad in its scope, and it shines with its great expansive dialog, huge item sets, and multiple playstyles. If you're new to the series, the gameplay for Divinity 2 is a positive mix of The Witcher and Diablo with an original, epic, story and top-knotch writing. It had the rare mix of being fun to play and fun to explore. I enjoyed playing it immensely.

This game is awesome. I picked it up and Beyond Divinity and Divine Divinity for five dollars during a steam sale. Best five dollars I've ever spent (although honestly, I would pay the regular $20 price tag.) I keep expecting the game to end but after 31 hours (with 95% of the sidequests finished) I realize I have only now hit the half-way point. Which is awesome. Lots of games end by the time you're powerful enough. A lot of reviews complain that the levelling doesn't make sense or the controls are awkward. If you've played Divinity: Original Sin and enjoyed it, then you'll probably enjoy this game. The writing or story isn't as good as in Original Sin but its still decent. The levelling is complicated in that if you don't want to start over a few times until you find a good build you should just look up a character guide. I spent 20 hours in Original Sin finding a good character set up, so I just went straight to a character guide. As far as the combat, its not the most polished, but its functional, works well, and is enjoyable.  The best part of the game is where you get to turn into a mother ♥♥♥♥ing dragon. I didn't even know you could do that when I bought the game. Its awesome. It makes travelling around really fast and if your human character is a little awkward when it comes to fighting, its the complete opposite for the dragon. Everything is smooth and fast and exciting.  I'd give it an 8/10. Definitely worth the $20 price from a game length aspect but you can easily pick it up for a lot less since it goes on sale pretty frequently.

Overwhelmingly underrated, exceptionally belittled, ferociously disregarded. Those were just some Stupidly-long descriptions, but the point is that this game is really really good: as generic as RPGs go, but that isn't a bad thing! Infact, it works in the game's favor! Sure, the graphics are less than stellar, but the audio is good and the combat & leveling are above average, there is A TON of stuff to do in-game and the writing as a whole is an exemple for all RPGs out there: it is smart, quirky, humorous and witty, by far the best part in the game. I found the puzzles to be somewhat of a challenge and i liked most of the characters (Did i mention the writing in this game?).  The storymode is divided into two parts: they are both interesting, and there is a really good twist between them. The best part about this game is that it doesn't hold your hand: you want to do something? it's up to you to figure out how to do it, you need to think in order to be successful, and that is very much appreciated. The game might be considered more of an Hack n' slash rather than a full-blown RPG, but that also works in the game's favor in my opinion. for this price, it is an absolute must. If you are lacking in money, or you might be a jew, wait for a discount (Please don't kill me i'm a jew this was just a joke...!!!).

When I bought the Divinity Anthology, I was really just buying it for this game (but I still soldiered through Divine Divinity at least first before jumping to this one). It was worthwhile playing through Divine Divinity - there's a lot of little callbacks and references to the world and previous events that made the experience of Divinity 2 more enjoyable.   Divinity 2 is a 3rd person Action RPG with a skill tree and stat allocation - think like a combination of World of Warcraft and Diablo. My wife said it reminded her of Dark Souls (or at least watching me play it) and I can see the resemblance. Overall the system works well - it's got a nice skill basis such that you can dodge around projectiles and attacks and avoid using potions and even kite enemies around if you're ranged. The options for character customization are broad too.   The world is large and full of character, and they definitely improved the quality of voiceover from Beyond Divinity. The plot is solid with an interesting (but apparently controversial) ending. Unfortunately it does fall into the trap of 'throw dozens of enemies at them' again, with the endgame becoming a -bit- of a trudge. They do close it out with a solid final area though.  The expansion pack sold the game for me though. They took the enemy count, toned it down, and made the majority of it venturing through one town fixing problems, talking to people, solving puzzles. One giant series of side quests, essentially. It was executed really well - and then they nailed the final sequence out of the park.   Playing through the first two Divinity games to get to Divinity 2 was definitely worth the wait - and I'd even recommend picking it up outside of the anthology if you don't care about the world-building done by the previous two games.

If you enjoy 3d action rpgs that don't take themselves too seriously but still offer an engaging story, loads of content and memorable characters, this game is for you. Overall certainly a great buy for the price, thoroughly enjoyed it :)

The styles aren't perhaps as balanced as they could be, and some play styles are harder than others. For example, I found melee classes much more challenging than ranged classes, and that influences how I played the game, despite my original intentons.   Currently this is on steam for £14.99. Not sure if I'd pay full price for Divinity II, but if you see this in a bundle anywhere, or on sale definitely snap it up.  7/10

This game has difficulty spikes that were supposed to have been fixed in the Dragon Knight Saga patch. It is unbearably painful to play in these difficulty spike areas, given how generic the combat is no matter how dumb the AI acts. This game starts off painfully to the point that I wouldn't recommend it, no matter what happens later on in the game, simply because it is too frustrating to get past the initial hurdle. If you want to play this game, know full well that it is easy to break a character build that will be unable to progress past future enemies, a flaw that they attempted to fix by cutting down enemy health and damage. Larian studios, although making improvements to their combat in their newer titles, completely failed here and left a mediocre combat system in this game. If you want to make a game functional, don't start off a player's stats at 1, this is not an mmo, though they certainly designed it to feel like one for the basic human character. At these stat levels, it was bound to happen that they would encounter problems balancing enemy levels and stats early on. On a plus, you at least have cool combat animations.  The jumping mechanic is glitchy at best, don't blame yourself if you jump in a stream and cannot get out easily. The ending is garbage and cliche, you spend the entire game listening to cutscenes of the villain making grandiose speeches in front of you. The expansion also has a mediocre ending, although it at least makes you happier than the base game with its conclusion. The engine is on par with TES Morrowind, but many times less enjoyable or memorable. The dragon mechanic is a cheap gimmick halfway through the game, with completely uninspired flight mechanics and nominal mmo interfacing. I can guarantee that half of the positive reviews are waxing nostalgia for the franchise, which is deserved given how much better its previous titles merit. Absolutely the worst of the franchise, skip it if you don't want to be screwed over by the story and forced through repetitive and pointless gameplay. The only upside is that the side quests are at least original and interesting in the choices you can make, never painting a black and white picture.  I honestly do not know how people tolerate this game to play it through. The core game is entirely flawed, such that there is a limited pool of XP, nothing respawns, you literally have to beat every side quest to have the XP to make a good character build. There is nothing enjoyable about the combat, it even takes away from the enjoyment of playing the game. It is a torture to try and beat the game when you are instantly dying because you didn't pick the boilerplate max stat character build. This game had so much potential, the combat engine ruined it entirely for me. I'm glad I got this on sale for less than three dollars, it is not worth anything more. I don't hate games often, but this has caused me serious grief and I regret every minute I spent playing it.  Before the Dragon Knight Saga, this game got between a 6 and a 7 on many review sites. Even with the Dragon Knight Saga, it still deserves the mediocre score, and nothing can redeem this game besides a complete re-make.
